job_title: Project Coordinator in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Love the mission, love 90% of the people involved in this mission. Being surrounded by brilliant people every day is an honor.
cons:
You will work 24/7. Being mission-driven, there are some very passionate people who have no work/life balance. They make it difficult for anyone else to try to maintain that balance.
Your well-being will vary greatly depending on who is your supervisor/on your specific team. Some managers are wonderful mentors who want to build up the folks around them, while others seem to want to break others down.

review_title: Application for the position of a professional driver
pros: I Pas is an NGO company that love to take the welfare of their staff as there first priority
cons: The contract finished at time I still want it to still continue

pros: Amazing mission in supporting women to access safe abortion. Extremely committed staff.
cons: Going through a difficult transition

pros: This organization is shifting to a decolonized model with the power being dissseminated to the countries. A noble effort.
cons: No one knows why or how things are happening. The leaadership has adopted so much new and quite frankly dizzying jargon. At the end of the day, everyone is exhausted and just waiting to see what happens.

pros: Great organization with competitive remuneration. Mission driven organization with a long range plan.
cons: Staffs are dedicated in terms of saving the job! A number of people supports anti-abortion but due to job at Ipas they raise their voice. Ultimately this impact on their dedication towards organization. Sometimes the supervisors trust the rumors about employees without proper checking.

pros: Lifting people up during the employment period. Good warm working environment
cons: Reward system for employees is not properly defined. Promotions are almost non existent

pros: For most US-based departments, flexibility and work-life balance are excellent. Supervisors generally trust employees to do their work. Staff are dedicated and mission-driven.
cons: No one at the organization is attending to to employee satisfaction and professional growth opportunities. Employees with depth of expertise are undervalued and lack power to contribute fully. Ipas is extremely heavy on process, wasting precious staff time that could be spent on mission-related activities. Ipas reputation as an authority on abortion is decreasing as capacity is wasted or people leave. Decisions are not made in a transparent way. Disaffected staff stay for the flexibility and salaries.

job_title: Communications Officer in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: Home office Work for women's rights Diversity
cons: Micromanagement You can't grow here You have to be connected all-day

pros: Very mission centric, Great benefits, remote and flexible work schedules, lots of support for it's employees. Management is not perfect, but you can see they are trying to dismantle hierarchical decision making and share leadership throughout the organization.
cons:
I think the "cons" are being addressed so I don't have too much to share. Many note inconsistency in management (inconsistent both from knowing how to lead people and an overall commitment to shared leadership) BUT there is work being done to help build those skills, and that takes time.
We are also hiring for vacancies across the organization which allows more diversity of thought and experience, and we're learning how to navigate the logistics of global hiring.

I see the commitment to doing the right thing, continually learning, and appreciate the increased transparency of changes and impact.

review_title: On it's last legs, move on, don't stop to look
job_title: Operations Supervisor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: There was a period of about 18 months around 2018 when the org expanded, the halls were abuzz with brilliant people, and there was an electricity to working there. Internal system investment was very good. Flexible schedules . Overseas travel (used to be)
cons: A once thriving org is now just a shadow of its former self. Only about 1/3 of the office remains, and just a handful of hangers on at the "home office". Downstairs is now being turned into a liquor store. A very caustic work environment exists, tracking directly back to the CEO/COO. No/low oversight of overseas offices leading to rampant issues with corruption, and harassment of staff members. Donors have known things were askew for a number of years, and even with warnings, the ship could not be righted. Several donors pulled their funding, leaving this org in a precarious position. Massive issues with diversity/inclusion. Most minority staff member were let go during the most recent RIF, or they were written out of their positions with job title changes. COO lets it be known that your opinion is not welcome. Essentially this is an old white ladies club, and if you're not a member, or member in waiting, there is no chance for you to be promoted, or to even be part of a change process.

review_title: If it's too good to be true, then it probably is
pros: Good benefits, wonderful field staff, nice HQ building
cons:
Incestuous management that continues to recycle existing people into key decision making positions that they aren't qualified for. HQ is mostly white American women with very few international staff. HQ staff makes much, much more for doing the same jobs as their field staff. There are limited to no opportunities for field staff to rotate into the HQ office and to be hired for long term positions in the HQ, creating an awkward balance of power between white Americans and the field teams. And most of the HQ staff have little to no substantive experience living and working in the countries they serve, thus creating a situation where the HQ teams have a very under-developed understanding of, and experience in working in culturally appropriate way. Many of us found HQ to have a very colonialistic attitude towards their field staff, assuming that field staff couldn't or wouldn't be able to work at the same levels when in fact the field teams were extremely qualified to do their jobs, more so than the HQ teams.

There were also issues with always hiring local staff to be Country Directors, creating fifedoms that would last for decades, and not in a good way.

review_title: Best Place to Work with Best People
pros:
1. Most efficient team
2. Keep employees before the organization
3. Great perks
4. Industry standard compensation
5. Great opportunity to learn
6. Innovative and open to feedback
cons: There are no cons that I can think of. May edit it later if I come across anything.

pros: Good company to work for
cons: Travel out of town might be a challenge for some

pros: The transparency, Autonomy you get here really motivate you to work in this office...
cons: You will have to work, workload is too much.

pros: Seems that the organization is challenging in an authentic way, the power structures that perpetuate colonialism in the global health and human rights sector.
cons: Shifting power away from the global north, but taking too long to define who makes decisions with what under the new model. Very stressful.

pros: Network of various professions across the world. Internal communication structures
cons: External communications. Clarity of roles and processes

pros: Culture of excellence, defined processes, supportive teams
cons: Low salaries, low promotion rates

pros:
Lots of learning resources
Flexibility
cons:
Lack of growth
Limited funding

pros: Ipas has done a great job at navigating through Covid. Their heart is in the right place with trying to dismantle colonialist power structures but the US staff are very nervous and keep leaving.
cons: Change is hard for people to focus when the future might mean the sunsetting of traditional hierarchies.

pros: A friendly environment and a great team.
cons: Working with IPAS always has been fun.

pros: Reasonable salary and steady annual increases, depending on the inflation rate and cost of living of the location of the job
cons: No clear career growth path, ambiguous performance reviews and limited promotion opportunities for staff

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
The benefits package, including healthcare, leave, and general flexibility for work, is a huge positive. This has particularly been the case during COVID-19, where staff have been given the flexibility to do what is in our best interest to stay safe and healthy while being able to care for our family. 
I also think that Ipas is going a good job moving forward towards a decentralized model of leadership and shifting the power out of the US office, and I am glad to see us take these steps forward in this space.
cons:
Your personal experience at Ipas can vary greatly based on your supervisor and your team. If you have a supportive and capable supervisor, you can feel more empowered to use your time off, seek professional development opportunities, etc.  
There are limited growth opportunities, particularly for lower-level staff, to advance. This is specifically the case for administrative staff looking to advance into a more technical role. 
As other posts mentioned, funding has been an issue recently (though this isn't limited to Ipas) and we are feeling the impacts of our most recent RIF.

review_title: This was a toxic work environment
job_title: Financial Analyst in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Absolutely nothing positive about this company, the environment, or the work life balance. The building did have a cool fingerprint reader to gain access, but I think that was due to the type of organization they are.
cons: With COVID this should not be an issue, but the parking was a nightmare due to its location in a shopping plaza. You can tell which region your colleague(s) worked in by their race/ethnicity. Minimal training and unrealistic expectations. If you have 20 countries they expect you do do the same things that someone with 6 countries was doing, and they constantly compared you to that person. Favoritism is the norm and expect to work long hours for below standard pay and benefits, especially if you are hired in their African region.

pros: Have good policies and systems
cons:
Toxic culture 
A lot of uncertainty employees are and off unceremoniously each year
Promotions and retentions based on who knows who

review_title: Great mission and amazing leadership support!
pros:
Great diversity within senior leadership and management team that includes leaders from the field teams! Progressive leadership that’s visionary and aligned to changing environment and culture within the Development NGO sector. 
Actively engaging staff from national and regional officers in organizational strategic discussions and decision making. Accountability and transformation some of the high level decisions are informed through engagement with staff in the field.
cons: Not unique to Ipas, funding shifts in this sector has resulted in funding cuts and loss of valuable staff talent within the organ and industry as a whole. This is compounded with shifts to move some aspects of INGO management oversight closer to the field resulting in reduced structures in global offices.

review_title: Great mission; strong, committed staff; supportive culture
pros: Mission-driven org; excellent benefits; strong leadership
cons: Unfortunately there have been some recent funding challenges

pros: Ipas has great HR policies at the global level although at country level there can be abuse of power.
cons: There can be abuse of power at country level. HQ needs to pay more attention to practices at country level.

pros: Areas/scope of Supervision and work support
cons: Staff development is very important

pros: If you want to be surrounded by supportive, smart, mission-driven colleagues, this is the place. If you feel strongly about the vision and mission, you'll have found your people. I feel lucky to be able to work for an organization with these "qualities". People here are valued for their skills, innovative thinking and deep commitment to social justice.
cons: It's not always easy. We work hard and we care deeply--that's a good thing but admit it can be challenging at times. It's a nonprofit and we live in an unstable world and that has meant some structural changes.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Ipas treats its employees with kindness and compassion that in my opinion is unparalleled. The benefits and compensation are very competitive compared to other organizations. Work life balance and flexibility is a strong plus point. Particularly during COVID-19, flexibility and ensuring staff are taking care of themselves and their families was emphasized across the organization. The pride people feel in their contribution towards organizational achievements creates a unifying thread among staff, allowing us to put the mission above any differences of opinions.

Ipas is a well-managed, innovative organization with immense strategic foresight. Despite all the challenges from COVID-19 and changes in industry funding trends, the organization remains nimble and able to adapt and stay relevant. The executive level management operates with the highest level of ethics and has been focusing on how the structure of the organization can support leadership, ideas, and priorities determined by Country Directors and other staff in the regions we have a presence. 

All executive team members and Directors follow an open-door policy, and a service leadership approach where they hear staff need needs, opinions, and advice to ensure work happens effectively and efficiently. Diversity and Inclusion is at the heart of Ipas’s culture. Our programmatic work always considers how we can reach the most marginalized communities in the countries where we work. In its own offices, Ipas has a diverse workforce that is culturally sensitive and forms a very inclusive environment. I have never felt more comfortable working in an organization and just being myself, and I enjoy the camaraderie with several other staff who identify with the same minority communities as I do.
cons: Changes in industry funding trends have resulted in a recent RIF. The dust is still settling on what new business processes etc. will look like with a reduced workforce in North Carolina. Diversifying funding sources will remain a priority, and a challenge, as the industry figures out how to continue the work being done by international NGOs for sexual and reproductive health, particularly when the need is so high due to COIVD-19 related challenges.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Benefits are wonderful 
Country Teams are incredible
cons: No plan for path forward, lots of ideas and no actionable path for those doing the work.

pros: Wonderful work culture, Amazing leadership, High Potential for Employee Growth
cons: Organization does not prefer freshers

review_title: Great Colleagues & Mission, with Some Flaws
pros:
Great mission
Full of really smart people who care tremendously about the work
Supportive work environment
cons:
Flaws in structure and placing priority in senior-level staff, organizational structure may prove difficult for continued success & donor investment in the long run
Happiness at the job & opportunities for advancement/doing the things you're interested in highly dependent on supervisor
Not much organizational investment in personal development

pros: very friendly to be here
cons: very good working environment and a place to be

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good company to work for
cons: hours are not too flexible

pros: The work to support the decision of women in controlling and deciding their reproductive health is inspiring. The organization leads in developing evidence to save the lives of women. Currently going through a signficant organizational pivot by decentralizing decisions to the country offices.
cons: Global funding environment is contracting making it hard to fund all the work

pros: Good work culture, values and ethics
cons: There are not many cons

pros: nice place to gain experience
cons: none i can tell so far

pros: Smart staff working towards a common purpose we believe in; caring leaders; supportive colleagues; intellectually stimulating; highly ethical workforce; fair compensation; great benefits. CEO is an inspiring leader with a deep passion for the mission.
cons: Challenging funding environment; relatively few opportunities for advancement.

review_title: Personal agendas, weak leadership, low morale
pros: Passionate and mission-driven staff teams across the world! I would come to work knowing that what I was going to do that day made a difference.
cons:
The CEO and COO didn’t take the time to learn about the organization’s fabric and all the positive things that made it a great NGO before making major decisions. It seems as if their personal agendas (and perhaps egos) took over. Yes, an organization can always become more efficient and effective, but the key to change is; 1) understanding the context and 2) implementing and communicating a plan that addresses that context with respect and empathy. The organizational restructure and voluntary/involuntary separation processes demonstrated a desire to impose their agenda and leave those behind that questioned or disagreed with that agenda. 

Since leaving, it seems as if employees continue to be nervous about job security and several young professionals have left. I believe this is a result of being frustrated with senior leadership and losing hope in their ability to successfully lead Ipas into the future.

pros: friendly environment, not a lot of stress
cons: some disorganization, unsure who does what

pros: working condition is good, everyone is important
cons: Organizational policies needs to be clear on area of promotions and disengagement of staff

pros: Salary and benefits are good, particularly for a non-profit. Staff are passionate about the mission and generally have a good sense of humor.
cons: By virtue of the size of the organization, there are limited career growth opportunities.

pros: Equitable workload and great benefits.
cons: It can be hard to advance.

pros: Great colleagues, benefits, mission, and leadership
cons: Nowhere to really grow into, no real career path

pros: They have a very good medical cover
cons: There is no pension for staff until a year into the job

pros: Payroll is timely. Some exceptional people worked there. Work life balance is better than most. Internal payroll and finance system upgraded to Workday recently. Severance packages during recent RIF were fair.
cons: Very odd management and executive structure. CEO is not active in the organization, but is a public face of the organization at conferences. COO runs all facets of the business down to the minutiae. Country Offices work as independent entities, with no oversight from the NC office. Recent closure of several overseas offices due to funding, and corruption issues. The board does not have management oversight, only a guiding mandate. Very hostile work environment. Recent RIF (3rd in the last 5 years), pushed out almost all minorities from the workplace. Diversity is a serious problem, unfortunately the Director of Diversity and Inclusion position was eliminated. During the RIF, all senior HR positions were eliminated. Corruption issues have been a major problem, unfortunately, the highly effective internal auditor position was also eliminated. Again, every facet of the business is run by the COO position, leading to a very unhealthy system of management. For those wishing to join the organization, please do your homework. A significant loss of revenue due to donor and performance issues has left the NC office (HQ) empty, and the overseas offices understaffed (or closed).

pros: Passion for mission, a lot of smart people to learn from
cons: Lack of trust and inclusion is an obstacle to feel free to truly bring all your expertise and observations to the table, silos, difficult to create progress

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Ipas houses some of the most brilliant young minds in the field today. There are so many intelligent people there with amazing ideas of how to move it forward, however, these are crushed consistently by upper management. The benefits were also generous in terms of vacation and sick leave.
cons: It still boggles my mind that Ipas does not provide a comprehensive maternity leave package. For being a women's rights organization, I would imagine that they would be among the leaders in exemplifying the importance of good maternity leave. Upper management is disastrous. They hire and promote only a few people who are there to further their careers and take credit for the work that lower employees do. Human Resources is also useless. You could be an employee undergoing some serious issues with your manager, and the manager will win no matter what. This leads to turnover from some of the most engaged people in the company. The atmosphere at Ipas is highly toxic, with palpable levels of stress and distrust. You will also be flooded with work, and then made to feel guilty when you request workload reassignments, with the mission looming over your head.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
My Ipas colleagues are a hard-working, impact and efficiency-driven, and fun-loving crew. COO is bright, energetic, motivational, and tireless in service of bringing positive change to Ipas and the women/girls we serve. Directors have significant overseas and non-Ipas work experience, bringing credibility, creative problem-solving, and diversity of thought to those positions and the org.

Ipas's push toward greater county autonomy and its long-standing practice of hiring local (not expat/TCN) employees in the field contributes to the feel good part of this place, in addition to being right for our mission, for the sustainability of our work, for local capacity, and for getting better bang for our donors' buck.

Good benefits: An earlier post indicated Ipas cut its paid maternity leave, which is simply not true.
cons:
Restructuring in Nov 2016 led to a significant number of long-time Ipas staff retiring (bitterly), which was unfortunate for morale. One part of the org was seemingly protected from the restructuring, which continues to be a pain point due to the inefficiencies in that part that remain from pre-restructure ways of working.

The new structure created strategic and overdue efficiencies, but likewise had to be "lived into" over the past six months to begin to feel the benefit of those efficiencies. Ipas is turning the corner and it's a joy to have these necessary, dramatic organizational lifecycle events getting ever-smaller in the rear view mirror!

job_title: Research Associate in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Passionate, dedicated engaged people from all over the world.
cons: A lot of workaholism with people feeling under valued and under appreciated.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The CEO and COO are  focused on implementing long desired changes in Ipas. They have tried their best not to get distracted by the personal agendas that often compete with realizing the vision they have for Ipas. They however have stayed on course and have decentralized the programming and focused the attention on the country programs who know best what their needs are.  It is quite possible that in the end Ipas will be better off because of the changes that have been implemented. Ipas remains a great place to get experience  for young professionals before moving on to other places where they can grow their careers.
cons: The long drawn out  layoffs and, restructuring left a traumatized staff that seems reticent to speak out and are paranoid about losing their jobs. The joyful events that characterized the Chapel hill office are long gone and are instead replaced by   hollow attempts to bring people together. It is not clear how one would grow in  Ipas because managers (who are probably priced out of the market)  seem focused on making themselves relevant which has resulted in   creating inefficiencies in the name of creating value. Younger staff  seem forgotten and are trickling out of  Ipas in a steady drip.

pros:
Friendly HR policies
Great working environment
cons: I dont have any cons for this organization

review_title: Go in with both eyes open.
pros: Brilliant, hardworking staff; vital mission and work; stellar country staff who are the brightest in the field; good benefits.
cons:
Leadership that has not a clue what positive change management looks like. Problematic promotions and perceived favoritism. Salary inequities among staff at similar or equal levels.

I must also add that I find some of the recent glowing reviews highly suspicious -- as if they were written by the current leadership. Ipas went through a brutal restructure. Friends and colleagues in corporate America have shared that it was more cut-throat than anything they've ever seen, a stark contrast to the legacy and culture of Ipas. Staff morale is abysmally low right now, and that's due in large part to the fact that there was no rhyme or reason (or explanation given) to some of the cuts. Longtime staff (many of whom were pioneers in the field) were given a choice to leave and most took the compensation deal and left with their heads held high. The involuntary cuts thereafter were done in the worst way possible with staff (some of whom were there for decades) being walked out the door by security and asked to collect their things the following weekend. There were and are problematic staff as well as inefficiencies, as in every organization, but I cannot imagine a worse way of handling the need for more streamlined leadership structures and processes than what happened recently at Ipas.

pros: Strong mission-driven organization; commitment to programmatic excellence; high caliber employees that go the extra mile; decent benefits (although that seems to be eroding); global leaders in the area of sexual and reproductive health; commitment to hiring in-country nationals rather than ex-pats; strong donor support
cons: Organization has new executive leadership (CEO and COO) that has little experience in the challenging mission of the organization, and did not seek extensive inputs from senior leadership during deliberations surrounding restructuring.  Most senior leaders left voluntarily or were asked to leave as part of restructuring, leaving a leadership vacuum; Organization is inept at managing change and staff suffer from change fatigue; implementation of financial management system was abysmal, although system functioning is gradually improving; the organization has just eliminated paid parental leave to which both women and men were eligible in favor of short-term disability for women only; Very low employee morale since restructuring in November; no clear vision for how to implement the new strategic plan

pros:
Great mission that attracts committed employees 
Niche areas where Ipas retains clear expertise and capacity 
Strong family-friendly culture 
Motivated employees 
Strong long-term donor base including many donors providing the organization with unrestricted funds which allow a lot of flexibility in how programs are delivered
cons:
Massive changes with new CEO and COO in place with unclear operational model moving forward and questionable decisions regarding changing senior leadership 
New CEO and COO not well-versed in the industry and inexperienced in running a non-profit. May be misreading industry trends and have made mistakes in describing the work when working with partners externally and with staff internally  
Recent large restructure done with out any involvement of staff (including Senior Directors) with unclear purpose for the restructure, unclear purpose of new units, and no plans made to transition staff workload through the restructure 
Ambition is to grow revenue quickly but unclear strategy in place for achieving this  
Dynamics between country offices and HQ-based staff can be challenging at times
Unclear use of (or process for prioritization) of unrestricted funds
Challenging new global financial system still not functional

pros: My colleagues are among the smartest, most competent, most dedicated people I have had the privilege to work with. Experts in their fields, all of them. I have learned and continue to learn from them every day. Everyone is focused on the mission, on rebuilding and improving the way we work. Strong relationships among staff. Innovative and creative thinkers. Good benefits.
cons: The leadership is new to the field and knows little about the basic practices of change management. The restructuring of the NC office was a shameful debacle, the follow-up work was either minimal or just minimally communicated. Morale continues to be low. Confusion continues to be high. Internal processes unclear. Efforts to dismantle silos seem to have resulted in more silos. Changes have resulted in starker hierarchies that have impeded communication.

review_title: Staying because of the underlying mission, colleagues despite significant challenges
pros:
Brilliant colleagues, some who take on the deep challenges with a measured bravery that inspires me. Very supportive and experienced middle managers and direct supervisors. Work life balance options and health benefits are good. Vacation and leave policies are good not great considering the field we are in.
This work is under attack from all sides; it's never been more important work than it is now!
cons: Non-transparent leveling has left people in the organization confused about where they fit and how/whether they are valued employees to Ipas as a whole. Some lasting inequities have been reinforced and gone unchanged with a new structure without a clear advocate or process for rectification. New CEO and COO are not visible during tough times and think they can simply re-write the mission and values of an organization with a long history and deep ties and commitment to communities. Some in upper management and human resources do not seem to understand that attaining health, access, and rights to abortion (or even the less principled though easier to sell "reducing unsafe abortion") is only possible when you acknowledge how power, stigma, race, and paternalism influence even the most user centered systems. The organization is losing amazing staff specifically some brilliant young women of color. I fear the next farewell email and mourn the loss of the energy to the organization and sometimes to the whole field as people who leave take jobs at less radically awesome organizations or in a related field. I leave the responsibility for all of the departures firmly at the doors of new upper management and the residual, unspoken effects of a deeply traumatic, multi-wave firing process.

review_title: Replace the chiefs with qualified leaders
pros: Great mission, passionate and committed staff. Used to have great organizational culture with friendly environment and good work/life balance.
cons:
The new CEO and COO have no business in their positions at Ipas. They lack relevant experience, and despite making many missteps with the organizational restructure and many management decisions thereafter, they fail to self-evaluate, listen to and learn from their staff, and course correct.
After sending aggressive "voluntary separation offers" to senior staff, the organization has lost most technical experts in the field of abortion, which has left a void in strategic vision and leadership. The organizational restructure eliminated high functioning units and maintained the least functioning units at headquarters, while also leaving staff in country offices overburdened with new responsibilities and no transitional support.
HR is out of touch, inexperienced, and apathetic about staff morale and fair compensation.

pros: You will work on exactly what you thought you would. When you get to Ipas, work hard, network and immediately start plans on your next job. Other organizations seem in awe of Ipas so you can trust that having  it on your resume will boost your career.  The work  you do will likely be challenging, enjoyable and you will feel like you are somehow impacting women and girls everywhere.  If you know the right people, have the right look and say the right things you will grow in your career and get paid handsomely.  The new CEO is a long time insider who is actually stable and pragmatic and will steady Ipas after a long period of turmoil.
cons:
If you are Caucasian and middle aged and are good at politics, you will thrive. Management often promotes friends and gives insanely high salaries if you use big words and can look the part of management. 

 If you are Caucasian and  young, get the experience and move on. It doesn't matter how many awesome ideas  you have, the older and often out of touch management will pretend to be excited and then let your innovative ideas die a slow painful death. 

If you are a minority.....of any age group... just work hard, get your experience and move on .....fast! There has not been a single successful effort at having leadership reflect the communities they serve. All diversity efforts have been met with passive resistance and no real energized effort to implement anything that closely resembles a diverse and inclusive workforce that actually works around the world.

review_title: Good people but terrible executive leadership.  Very frustrating and political.
pros: Most of the people are very dedicated and mission oriented.  It feels good to be a part of something that saves lives.
cons: The senior leadership has horrible management skills and creates a very dysfunctional corporate culture.  It's hard to move up because a lot of managers are "lifers",

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Ipas is a fantastic mission driven organization that values its staff and provides them with career development opportunities. Its a flat organization and everyone all the way to the most senior levels of management practice open door policy.
cons: I'm yet to find any significant cons that are specific to Ipas. Like any other organization, it has a mix of people that one works well with, and some one would find challenging.

review_title: Good: work/life balance. Bad: lack of opportunity for growth
pros: The organization bends over backwards to support work/life balance. The work is interesting and supports an important mission. If you're in the right department, there are opportunities for international travel.
cons: Very little opportunity for career growth as there is not much movement among senior staff. Internal politics often drive decision making.  Still, it's a good place to work for a few years, or longer if career advancement/promotion isn't a priority.

pros: Passionate employees; family-friendly culture; lenient work from home policies; average benefit package
cons: Oblivious executive officers; inexperienced leadership; cut-throat middle managers; a nonsensical org structure; an inept Finance department; an apathetic HR unit; low staff morale; high turnover rate

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Good work/life balance with dedicated co-workers. I feel strongly supported and trusted in my role. I love the prevailing appetite for innovation, experimentation, and risk taking that opens many doors for those hungry for a challenge.
cons: Still going through a period of significant change. While I am confident about the direction taken, there is still quite a bit of uncertainty with regards to how we will get there as an organization.

review_title: Pretty great most of the time
pros: Wonderful, intelligent, hardworking, caring colleagues, awesome mission, interesting work, lots of opportunities and things to get involved with. Competitive pay and benefits. New CEO is communicative about changes that are happening,
cons: Managers often lack management skills/training, organization sometimes take on too much, have difficulty maintaining focus and priorities, doesn't give country programs enough autonomy over programs, structure is often in effective, difficult HR department.

pros: I get to do work that I love everyday in support of a cause I believe in. The benefits I'm offered working here are far better than what I've had working for other employers. The CEO and Executive Team members are approachable and always looking for feedback and ways to improve. I look forward to interacting with my colleagues everyday.
cons: Our mission is a little more controversial than the average non-profit so it may not be the right fit for everyone.

pros: The passion and mission of co-workers is inspiring.  The openly multi-culture environment broadens one's perspective on other aspects of life.  Management is trying...lots of changes and adjustments.  From personal experiences,  as an employer, they are extremely tolerant.
cons: Disappointed in attitudes and perspectives and expectations that employees get a "buy-in" on many decisions.  Not a reality in the for profit employment arena.

pros: New Leadership (Chiefs) is rationale, empowering, and mission/vision-focused. They are working to improve Ipas' cost-effectiveness and therefore increase our global impact. Change can be difficult and the road rough, but the vision is sound. The changes they are bringing are LONG long overdue and have improved staff engagement and productivity in many areas of the org.
cons: Still some growing pains to iron out but not unexpected.

pros: Lots of learning opportunities and higher ups are always willing to take the time to connect you to potential mentors across departments and teach. Open-minded and collaborative environment!
cons: Only spent a short time there provided temporary assistance, but I would have liked a more steady workload. There were very active periods where I was kept on my toes, but then lulls where I was left twiddling my thumbs.

pros: Caring organisation.  Work load is busy, but the company cares about work-life balance, and there is no demand to work after hours or on weekends.
cons: A lot of the employees who have been with the organisation for a long time are very touchy, and sensitive to any form of criticism.  There is a lot of employee expectation from their employer which is not realistic sometimes.

pros: Good mission and benefits. A number of nice people.
cons: It's hypocritical to be working in underserved communities but have a head office that entertains discrimination and pays no attention to the lack of equity and inclusion which has (very sadly) tickled down to in-country offices.  This is an organization where there are two groups: chosen ones who run the show, and the unimportant ones who have to take it, or leave it. If you are lucky to be welcomed to the club of the chosen few, you might survive. God forbid you belong to the other group.....you're on your own! I'm yet to meet a black person who feels/felt welcome and aporeciated. To call it as it is, this organization suffers from a good measure of white supremacy - in terms of race, ideals, and ideas. A lot of incrimination that is simply ignored. And what the hell is HR's work? Just hire and fire and dish out unnecessary PIPs as directed by the chosen few? How bizarre?  What's even more unfortunate is that the chosen few are so stuck in their privilage that they actually don't realize how hateful and hurtful they are to others. The culture here is - the more big/technical words you get out of your mouth, the more you are celebrated by the powers that be. This has led to people being placed in managerial positions with zero leadership skills, distressing those who report to them. Come on now, we all know that big words really mean nothing to the woman and girl in a deep rural village where we work. Favoritism is also rampant! As long as you are in the chosen few club, management will do anything they can to accommodate you. Poor performance....no problem! You will get a second, third, fourth chance. You will actually be moved to another position. Not in the club? ....you are automatically placed on the so called performance improvement plan - just as a way of signaling your way out. So, one must chose between staying until they're shown the door or leaving on their own before it comes. For many, this culture is intolerable and they're constantly looking for the next exit.

pros: The mission is inspiring and the organization is working at the cutting edge.  The North Carolina and country staff members are passionate and highly skilled. The current CEO has righted the ship after a few years of rocky leadership.
cons: The size of the organization doesn't always allow for internal promotions.

review_title: Ipas is a good place to start your career and learn in your early carrer.
pros:
Competitive Salary and Benefits
The mission 
People
Coffee
cons:
Management lacks of a clear strategic/vision of the organization. 
Lack of transparency strategic decision
Diversity and Inclusion
 When they have funding problems, management prefers to cut all junior positions and keep all executive positions, which can be more costly in the long run and contradictory to the humanitarian mission.
Their is lack of human, equity treatment, unless you belong to the favorites white girls group.

pros: You really feel you are contributing to others' wellbeing and that your colleagues are committed to the work you do.
cons: Some of the other staff members get a little carried away with their pro-company attitude and the objectives of the organization...lose a little focus.

pros: An opportunity to be part of a team that gives back to the community by providing access to resources not available to everyone
cons: The working hours are crazy, a lot of paperwork involved, structures not fully developed and information on training and career growth opportunities not readily available

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Passionate and talented colleagues, who have extensive technical and programmatic experience, and are deeply committed to the organizational mission.
cons: New leadership are ill equipped to do their job and should be replaced by actual experts in the field who put human rights at the core of their approach to the work they do.

pros: Great mission, colleagues, opportunity to meet people from around the world
cons: Downsides are minimal; challenge of working on issues that are not universally supported

job_title: Program Advisor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The company culture is very positive. Lots of opportunities to grow in different health niches. Some may even result in sending you to different parts of the world.
cons: The organization structure is somewhat confusing and unclear.

pros: Great mission, great people in junior and mid-level roles.
cons: See other recent reviews-- very accurate!

pros: very good atmosphere,bosses,colleagues,support system,freedom of work
cons: no universal and transparent salary structure

pros: Niche area to work in
cons: Poor management driven by perceptions, lot of office politics

pros: The work is good, and can go to greater heights
cons: Too much internal politics, some senior management people are horrible. They are full of ego and also are stupidly insecure.

pros: Very important goals being sought in Nigeria's ever difficult reproductive healthcare environment
cons: Unnecessarily petty local staff. A lot of office politics going on in the background. Things got dramatic very easily.

pros:
It’s a great place to work 
Works on quality

5 days work in a week

pros: Good benefits, training, and guidance.
cons: Though the organization had tried it's best to have a good relationship between employees, I saw the division in team.

review_title: Making changes but still not good
pros: The mission and the work are important.  It feels good knowing you are making a difference in women and girls' lives around the world.
cons: Leadership is inexperienced and inconsistent. They play favorites and often hire people based on who they know and not what they know.

pros: Good place to work. Would love to work again.
cons: No cons. Had a wonderful experience

pros: Great work life balance and great co-workers
cons: Lots of politics at some level in the organization

pros: Championing advancing of sexual and reproductive health and rights
cons: A political institution, staff favoritism; restructuring not fairly done

pros: Flexibility, supportive managers, professional development highly prioritized

review_title: Ipas - looks great from the outside but...............
pros: Salary was generous and benefits were excellent, particularly healthcare and vacation.
cons: The Development Department in this company will make your life miserable.  The EVP micromanages and the Development Director is superfluous.
